Dear Ms. Hill,
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 08/22/24. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents, as
follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial
removal and at least once every 90 calendar
days thereafter.
Three foster care files and 9 service plans were reviewed. One of three files
contained a service plan that was completed late.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case
Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date. Note: This FTM may be combined with
the CPS Case Opening (ISP) FTM. Updated Case Plan
(USP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan
due date. Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) -
within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.

The caseworker must enter the FTM information in the
electronic case management record using the FTM
hyperlink within seven business days of the FTM.
Two of three foster care files documented FTM’s that were uploaded beyond the
time frame required by policy. One of three files documented an FTM occuring
more than 30 days from the service plan due date. This same file was missing an
FTM for a service plan period.
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
Once completed and approved, the caseworker
must obtain signatures from the following
individuals, as applicable:
• Caseworker. • Supervisor. • Second line
supervisor, when siblings in care are placed apart. •
Parents who are a member of a participating
household. • Youth ages 14 and older. • Foster
parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court
ordered caregivers.
Three foster care files and nine service plans were reviewed. Three of three files
each documented late signatures on two service plans. Therefore, the signature
pages were not uploaded into the electronic case record within 30 days of the
report date.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
09/08/2022 Renewal, CAP Approved 09/27/2022
9/25/23 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/16/23.
FOM 801-03 Medical Passports
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect
the child's current and complete health information.
Two of three foster care files reviewed were lacking one or more medical
passport updates.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
09/08/2022 Renewal, CAP Approved 09/227/2022.
9 /25/23 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/16/23.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Rule 400.12415 (a) Incident reports. Discussed the requirement that incident
reports are to be submitted to the consultant. Only those incidents named under
the rule are to be submitted.
• DCWL review of Corrective Action Plans (CAP). The agency was informed
that starting January 1, 2024, interim and renewal audit CAP's will be reviewed
with the agency at three months and six months. The assigned Consultant for the
agency will work with the agency in conducting CAP reviews. This process for
special investigation CAP reviews was implemented previously.
• Rule 400.12209 (2) (a) Orientation and Training. The agency was informed
that all the training requirements listed under (2) (a) are required yearly for foster
care workers carrying a caseload as well as for supervisors who may be carrying
a caseload.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was not requested or provided at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The agency submitted an approved CAP on 11/14/23 in response to violations
established during the interim inspection completed on 09/25/23. The current
renewal inspection established repeat violations of FOM-722-08D Treatment plans
and FOM 801-03 Medical Passports. The CAP was successful in preventing
repeat violations of R 400.12326 Borrowed Home and Rule 400.12421 Visitation
and Family time - in person.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed. The assessment addressed
violations established during the Interim inspection completed on 09/25/2023. The

assessment detailed how staffing issues continue to impact the agency's efforts to
comply with the rules. The assessment reports that filling vacant positions is
difficult due to an ongoing lack of qualified applicants in the greater Traverse City
area. The assessment also reported that there were four unplanned discharges in
the past year. The report states that child behavioral problems and foster parents
requesting removal contributed to the unplanned discharges.
Financial Overview
The agency's annual budget was reviewed as well as an annual certified public
audit. The review of the documents did not establish any concerns.
Staff Interviews
Staff reported feeling supported by their respective supervisors and feel they are
part of a committed, supportive team.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency is a modern well maintained facility in Traverse City. There is
sufficient office space and rooms for family visitation. CHRI documents were
observed to be secured appropriately.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
Safety Alert #1: A safety alert was generated on 07/11/24 as the home did not have
a smoke alarm between sleeping areas and the rest of the home.
Resolution: This was addressed on 07/12/24. Photos of alarms were uploaded.
Safety Alert #2: was generated on 07/11/24 as a smoke alarm was not located
between the bedrooms and the rest of the home.
Resolution: This was addressed on 07/15/24. Photos of installed alarms were
uploaded.
Safety Alert #3: was generated on 07/31/24 as a smoke alarm was missing between
the master bedroom and the rest of the home.
Resolution: This was addressed on 08/02/24 as the alarm was installed and photos
were provided and uploaded.

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
